case_data.name: Gonzales & Gonzales Bonds & Insurance Agency, Inc. v. United States Department of Homeland Security
case_data.plaintiff_description: A group of bond agents and surety companies who post immigration bonds.
case_data.summary:
On December 14, 2020, a group of agents and surety companies who post immigration bonds filed a complaint against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. Seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, the suit challenged a Final Rule which mandated exhaustion of administrative remedies by a Treasury-approved surety or its agent when challenging the breach of an immigration bond. In filing an administrative appeal, sureties and their agents were required to include all defenses to the government’s bond breach declarations, but without the government being required to produce relevant documents and without sufficient time for the surety or agent to discuss the circumstances of the bond breach with the noncitizen. This, the complaint alleged, amounted to a violation of the due process clause. Specifically, the complaint alleged that the Final Rule created an unequal application of the law as cash bond obligors are not required to exhaust their administrative remedies, thereby constituting an equal protection violation. The plaintiffs further claimed that the Rule was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), both because it was arbitrary and capricious and because it was issued under Acting Secretary Wolf who was not validly appointed. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel, and the case was assigned to Magistrate Judge Kandis A. Westmore. 

On March 29, 2021, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss alleging the plaintiffs did not have Article III standing as no adverse action had been taken against them under the Final Rule they sought to challenge. The court granted the motion to dismiss on July 13, 2021. In doing so, the court found that the plaintiffs had failed to sufficiently allege an injury-in-fact that satisfied Article III’s standing requirement. 2021 WL 5002220. 

Following the court’s order, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on August 3, 2021. The complaint realleged the same claims, but noted that since the Final Rule was promulgated the plaintiffs had filed over a thousand immigration bonds, and DHS had wrongfully declared breaches of a significant number of those bonds. 

On August 21, the defendants again filed a motion to dismiss for still lacking standing. The defendants claimed that the plaintiffs’ claims were still not ripe because they had suffered no injury under the Final Rule and because a ruling in their favor cannot redress their speculative future injury. On October 19, 2021, the court denied the motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs did sufficiently allege an injury and ripeness of their claims this time around. 2021 WL 5002221. 

Following the filing of the administrative record, the plaintiffs filed a motion for summary judgment on May 12, 2022. The plaintiffs did so on grounds that the rule was unlawfully promulgated, specifically because Acting Secretary Wolf lacked authority to issue it. After briefings on the matter, the government also notified the court of a Third Circuit opinion in the case Kajmowicz v. Whitaker (3rd Cir. 2022), which held that where a new and properly appointed agency official ratifies a Rule, the fact that an Acting official may have lacked the authority to initially issue it will not impact a rule’s ultimate lawfulness. Plaintiffs then noted that subsequent ratification in this case cannot cure the issuance of a final rule promulgated by an unauthorized official. 

On August 10, 2022, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment and entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs. 2022 WL 4596611. The defendants then appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit (22-16552) in October. 

On appeal, the parties began with mediation conferences and filed briefs on the issue. Oral arguments were ultimately scheduled for October 19, 2023. The Ninth Circuit’s final ruling then came down on July 18, 2024 wherein the court reversed the district court’s decision. The court held that the Federal Vacancies Reform Act of 1998 (“FVRA”) did not bar Secretary Mayorkas from ratifying the Final Rule, and that ratification cured any defects in the Rule’s initial promulgation, including Acting Secretary Wolf’s issuance of the Rule. The court, thus, found that the district court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings. 107 F.4th 1064. 

Following the Ninth Circuit’s mandate, the parties submitted a case management statement in January 2025 regarding next steps, noting that trial would not be expected. The plaintiffs noted that they were evaluating whether or not to file a Petition for Certiorari. The defendants noted that partial summary judgment ought to be granted in their favor considering the Ninth Circuit’s opinion. 

In a February 2025 case management statement, the plaintiffs stated they would not be filing a Petition for Certiorari. The plaintiffs also noted that they intended to challenge the completeness of the administrative record previously submitted and to seek further discovery on this issue. On March 3, 2025, the court then set a case management conference for June 3, 2025. 

On March 4, the court ordered the parties to meet and confer regarding the administrative record issues, and ordered the defendants to produce a privilege log. On March 6, the defendants filed a motion requesting leave to file a motion seeking reconsideration of the court’s March 4 order to produce the privilege log. 

The case, thus, remains ongoing on remand.

2  revocation if there is an outstanding unpaid bond obligation.  Nor are these regulatory 
3  “changes,” as claimed by DHS.  Rather, they are entirely new regulations.  And there is no 
4  reference in these regulations to any recently passed legislation authorizing them.   
5  53.  These regulations effectively grant DHS the authority to revoke a surety’s 
6  certification by bypassing the one and only statutory scheme governing revocation of a surety’s 
7  certification.     
8  D.  Only Treasury Has Limited Authority to Prevent a Surety from Conducting 
9  Business  
10  54.  By providing agencies such as DHS with the authority to refuse bonds from 
11  certain sureties, the Final Rule conflicts with 31 U.S.C. 9304-9308, which specifically authorize 
12  Treasury to certify and decertify sureties posting federal bonds.  The “background” section of 
13  the Final Rule confirms that Treasury is responsible for administering the corporate Federal 
14  surety bond program under the authority of 31 U.S.C. §§ 9304-9308.  Treasury does not have 
15  the right to delegate, by regulation or otherwise, its exclusive authority to administer federal 
16  surety bonds. 
17  55.  31 U.S.C. 9305 clearly and unambiguously provides that Treasury may revoke 
18  the authority of a surety corporation to do new business only if (1) the Secretary decides the 
19  corporation is insolvent, or (2) is in violation of sections 9304, 9305 or 9306.  None of these 
20  three sections authorize DHS to reject a bond issued by a surety who has an outstanding unpaid 
21  bond obligation that DHS contends is due and owing.  
22  56.  31 U.S.C. 9305(e) precludes the writing of an additional bond only if the surety 
23  has not paid a final judgment that has not been appealed.  The Final Rules allows DHS to 
24  replace this “final judgment” provision of 31 U.S.C. 9305(e) with DHS’s claim that there are 
25  “past due” invoices on “administratively final breach determinations.”  A final judgment is no 
26  longer required even though Congress specified this requirement.  DHS’s utilization of a 
27  standard that is far more stringent than the standard Congress has provided to Treasury violates 
28  due process and runs afoul of specific Congressional intent on the subject.

1  57.  There is no authority for these changes to the code section.  The regulations 
2  impermissibly alter statutory mandates and create new law by allowing DHS to administer the 
3  Federal surety bond program.  The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected such regulations.  In Bowen 
4  v. Georgetown University Hosp., 488 U.S. 204, 208 (1988), the Court held that it is axiomatic 
5  that an administrative agency’s power to promulgate legislative regulations is limited to the 
6  authority delegated by Congress. 
7  58.  In Manhattan General Equipment Co. v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 297 
8  U.S. 129, 134-135 (1936), emphasis added, the Court held that: 
9  “[t]he power of an administrative officer or board to administer a federal 
10  statute and to prescribe rules and regulations to that end is not the power 
11  to make law, for no such power can be delegated by Congress, but the 
12  power to adopt regulations to carry into effect the will of Congress as 
13  expressed by the statute.  A regulation which does not do this, but 
14  operates to create a rule out of harmony with the statute, is a mere nullity 
15  . . . And not only must a regulation, in order to be valid, be consistent 
16  with the statute, but it must be reasonable.”  
17  59.  Further, where a Treasury statute is unambiguous, and its directions specific, 
18  there is no power to amend it by regulation.  Koshland v. Helvering, 298 U.S. 441, 446-447, 56 
19  S.Ct. 767, 769 - 770 (1936).  See also Goodson-Todman Enterprises, Ltd. v. Commissioner, 784 
20  F.2d 66, 74 (2d Cir.1986) (“A Treasury regulation may therefore be declared invalid . . . if it is 
21  unreasonable or clearly contrary to the language or spirit of the statute it purports to 
22  implement”).   
23  60.  Congress delegated to Treasury (rather than DHS) the sole authority to decertify 
24  sureties because Treasury has expertise in financial matters and the financial surveillance of 
25  sureties authorized to write federal bonds.  DHS does not have the expertise to conduct due 
26  process hearings regarding the value of a security, and more importantly, DHS has a conflict of 
27  interest in conducting such proceedings because its goal in refusing to accept immigration 
28  bonds is to force the surety to pay invoiced bonds, even though the underlying breaches may be

1  66.  First, DHS treats a single, $50,000 immigration bond invoice the same as ten 
2  invoices which may total far less than $50,000.  Treating a single bond breach as equivalent to

5  67.  Another “for cause” standard uses a breach rate calculation.  DHS proposes to 
6  take the number of bond breaches from October 1 to September 30 of the preceding year and

14  A surety may have several cancellations a few days or weeks before the start of a fiscal year or

4  G.  DHS’s Review Has Proven Futile  
5  73.  The Final Rule authorizes DHS to administer the Federal surety bond program 
6  even though DHS has been found in court decisions to not abide by its agreements and

1  COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF  
2  1.  This case challenges a final rule that was unlawfully promulgated by a DHS 
3  official that several courts have now held was not lawfully serving in his role.  It was issued 
4  under Chad Wolf, who assumed the title of Acting Secretary of the Department of Homeland 
5  Security without constitutional or statutory authority. 
6  2.  The final rule (1) mandates administrative exhaustion for a Treasury-approved 
7  surety or its agent to challenge the government’s breach of an immigration bond without 
8  providing due process safeguards to allow for fair and impartial administrative review, (2) 
9  drastically increases the cost for administrative review, and (3) creates arbitrary criteria to 
10  determine whether a Treasury-approved surety can continue to post immigration bonds.  85 Fed. 
11  Reg. 45,968 (July 31, 2020) (“Final Rule”).   
12  3.  The Final Rule requires that a Treasury-approved surety or its agent file an 
13  appeal of a bond breach claim by the government, and to include all defenses to the bond 
14  breach, without the government (1) producing documents supporting its breach determination, 
15  (2) producing documents to allow the surety and its agent to identify available defenses under 
16  the terms of the bond or mitigate damages claimed by DHS, and (3) allowing sufficient time for 
17  the surety or agent to discuss the circumstances of the bond breach with the alien or indemnitor.   
18  4.  This violates the due process rights of the sureties and their agents because any 
19  defense not raised in the administrative appeal is prohibited from being raised in subsequent 
20  litigation in federal court.  Further, if the surety or its agent do not file an administrative appeal 
21  within 30 days of receiving of a breach notice, they are precluded from challenging the bond 
22  breach in federal court.   
23  5.   With administrative exhaustion now required, the Final Rule increases the cost 
24  for a Treasury-approved surety to dispute the government’s breach of an immigration bond 
25  from $0 to $675, making it more expensive to challenge an immigration bond breach than it is 
26  to file a petition with the United States Supreme Court.  With the penal amount of certain 
27  immigration bonds set at $500, it now costs more to dispute the breach of certain bonds than it 
28  does to pay the bond.

1  6.  The Final Rule also creates such a low threshold for debarment of a surety that

SUMMARY* 
Federal Vacancies Reform Act 
In an action in which companies that post immigration 
surety bonds challenged a Department of Homeland Security 
(“DHS”) rule on the ground that the Acting Secretary of 
DHS who promulgated the rule was not duly appointed, the 
panel reversed the district court’s summary judgment in 
favor of Plaintiffs and remanded.  
An immigration bond secures a promise that an alien will 
appear  for  immigration  proceedings.   In  2020,  Acting 
* This summary constitutes no part of the opinion of the court.  It has

GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS  3 
Secretary Chad Wolf promulgated a rule permitting DHS to 
refuse business from certain surety firms (the “Rule”).  But, 
as the panel explained, Wolf was not duly appointed under 
the applicable law and thus lacked authority to promulgate 
the  Rule.   In  2021,  Secretary  of  Homeland  Security 
Alejandro Mayorkas, who was duly appointed, ratified the 
Rule.   
The panel held that the Federal Vacancies Reform Act of 
1998 (“FVRA”) did not bar Mayorkas from ratifying the 
Rule, and that ratification cured any defects in the Rule’s 
promulgation.  The panel explained that the Ratification Bar, 
5  U.S.C.  § 3348(d)(2),  prohibits  ratification  of  certain 
actions taken by a purported officer serving in violation of 
the FVRA.  The panel concluded that the Ratification Bar 
applies  only  to  “functions  or  duties”  that  are 
“nondelegable.”   By  the  statute’s  own  definition,  the 
Ratification Bar applies only to nondelegable functions or 
duties because only nondelegable functions or duties are 
“required by statute [or regulation] to be performed by the 
applicable  officer  (and  only  that  officer).”   5  U.S.C. 
§3348(a)(2).
Judge Johnstone concurred in the lead opinion except for
its conclusion that the meaning of the phrase “the applicable 
officer (and only that officer)” is plain.  Looking to extrinsic 
evidence from the court’s co-equal branches to resolve this 
ambiguity,  Judge  Johnstone  nonetheless  concluded  that 
“function or duty” includes only the officer’s nondelegable 
duties.  
Dissenting, Judge Christen wrote that the text, structure, 
and purpose of the FVRA make clear that application of the 
ratification  bar  does  not  turn  on  whether  a  duty  is 
delegable.  Rather, the ratification bar applies to all functions 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 71   Filed 07/18/24   Page 4 of 64
4  GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS 
and duties that Congress assigns to a single officer (and 
excludes functions and duties that Congress authorizes more 
than one officer to perform).  Judge Christen wrote that the 
majority’s decision renders the FVRA a near-dead letter by 
deciding that the FVRA does not apply to the vast majority 
of  actions  taken  by  officials  serving  in  violation  of  the 
FVRA.

OPINION 
BEA, Circuit Judge: 
In  certain  immigration  cases,  the  Department  of 
Homeland Security (“DHS”) requires a bond—similar to a 
bail bond in criminal cases—to avoid detention of the alien 
pending deportation.  The bond secures a promise that the 
alien will appear for immigration proceedings, which will 
determine whether the alien can remain in the United States. 
Commercial firms, known as sureties, provide such bonds. 
In 2020, the “Acting Secretary” of the DHS promulgated a 
rule that permitted the agency to refuse business from certain 
surety  firms  that  were  serially  delinquent  in  making 
payments  for  absconding  aliens  or  that  had  garnered  a 
reputation for posting bonds for frequent absconders.  See 
Procedures and Standards for Declining Surety Immigration 
Bonds  and  Administrative  Appeal  Requirement  for 
Breaches, 85 Fed. Reg. 45968, 45968–69 (July 31, 2020) 
(the “Rule”). 
But some of those sureties that were not too fond of this 
new Rule, which cut into their business, realized that the 
“Acting Secretary” who promulgated the Rule may not have 
been duly appointed.  Hence, the Rule might be invalid and 
the sureties might have been improperly banned from doing 
business with the DHS. 
Unfortunately  for  the  sureties’  pretensions,  in  2021 
Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas, who 
was duly appointed, ratified the Rule.  But that leaves the 
question—does the exercise of ratification cure the alleged 
defect in the Rule’s promulgation?  We hold that it does. 
Under  principles  of  agency  law  and  Circuit  precedent, 
Secretary Mayorkas had the authority to ratify an action 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 71   Filed 07/18/24   Page 6 of 64
6  GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS 
taken by an improperly appointed Acting Secretary, who 
would not otherwise have been authorized to take that action. 
See Consumer Fin. Prot. Bureau v. Gordon, 819 F.3d 1179, 
1190–92 (9th Cir. 2016).  But there was a possible hurdle to 
the exercise of ratification.  Under the so-called “Ratification 
Bar,” Secretary Mayorkas could not ratify promulgation of 
the Rule if such promulgation could be performed only by 
the Secretary of Homeland Security himself.  See 5 U.S.C. 
§3348(a)(2), (d)(2).
We conclude that the Secretary had the authority to
delegate promulgation of the Rule; it was not a function or 
duty singularly entrusted to the Secretary.  See 6 U.S.C. 
§112(b)(1).  Because the Secretary could have delegated
promulgation of the Rule, Secretary Mayorkas could ratify
the 2020 promulgation of the Rule, regardless whether the
Rule’s promulgation had been actually delegated.  Thus,
ratification of the Rule by Secretary Mayorkas cured any
defect in the Rule’s promulgation.
The  question  in  this  case  is  whether  5  U.S.C. 
§3348(d)(2),  the  Ratification  Bar,  which  prohibits
ratification of certain actions taken by a purported officer
serving in violation of the Federal Vacancies Reform Act of
1998 (“FVRA”), applies only to “functions or duties” that
are  singularly  entrusted  by  statute  or  regulation  to  that
officer, and in other words are “nondelegable.”  We hold that
it  does.    By  the  statute’s  own  definition,1  § 3348(d)’s
Ratification Bar applies only to nondelegable functions or
duties because only nondelegable functions or duties are
“required by statute [or regulation] to be performed by the
applicable  officer  (and  only  that  officer).”    5  U.S.C.
1 Judge Johnstone concurs in this opinion, except for its conclusion that 
the meaning of the statute is plain and unambiguous.  Con. Op. 33–34. 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 71   Filed 07/18/24   Page 7 of 64
GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS  7 
§3348(a)(2).  Thus, we hold that the district court erred in
granting Plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment because
the FVRA did not bar Secretary Mayorkas from ratifying the
Rule, and that ratification cured any defects in the Rule’s
2020 promulgation.
I. BACKGROUND
Article II of the Constitution gives the President the
authority to appoint “Officers of the United States,” but 
requires the President to obtain the “Advice and Consent of 
the Senate” to make those appointments effective.  U.S. 
CONST. art. II, § 2, cl. 2.  To avoid negative repercussions of 
vacancies in those positions, “Congress has long accounted 
for th[e] reality” of vacancies “by authorizing the President 
to direct certain officials to temporarily carry out the duties 
of a vacant . . . office in an acting capacity, without Senate 
confirmation.”  NLRB v. SW Gen., Inc., 580 U.S. 288, 293 
(2017).  The current version of that authorization is the 
FVRA, 5 U.S.C. §§ 3345–49e. 
Under the FVRA, when an Executive agency officer 
“whose appointment to office is required to be made by the 
President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, 
dies, resigns, or is otherwise unable to perform the functions 
and duties of the office[,] the first assistant to the office of 
such officer shall perform the functions and duties of the 
office  temporarily  in  an  acting  capacity,”  5  U.S.C. 
§3345(a)(1),  unless  the  President  selects  either  another
officer who was previously Presidentially appointed and
Senate-confirmed or an officer or employee of the same
agency who has served a specified time in that agency, id.
§3345(a)(2)–(3).
The  FVRA  is  the  “exclusive  means  for  temporarily
authorizing an acting official to perform the functions and 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 71   Filed 07/18/24   Page 8 of 64
8  GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS 
duties of any office of an Executive agency . . . for which 
appointment is required to be made by the President, by and 
with the advice and consent of the Senate, unless a statutory 
provision expressly authorizes the President, a court, or the 
head of an Executive department” to designate the acting 
officer,  a  statute  designates  the  acting  officer,  or  the 
President makes an appointment during a Senate recess.  Id. 
§3347(a).
In  December  2016,  President  Obama  exercised  his
authority under § 3345(a) to establish an order of succession 
for the Office of Secretary of Homeland Security in case of 
an office vacancy.  Exec. Order No. 13753, 81 Fed. Reg. 
90667 (Dec. 9, 2016) (“Executive Order 13753”).  Later that 
month, Congress amended the Homeland Security Act to 
give  the  Secretary  of  Homeland  Security  independent 
authority to create an order of succession, but did not change 
the order of succession established by President Obama’s 
Executive Order 13753.  National Defense Authorization 
Act for Fiscal Year 2017, Pub. L. No. 114-328, § 1903, 130 
Stat. 2000, 2672 (2016) (codified at 6 U.S.C. § 113(g)).  
President Obama signed the Act, and it became law. 
A. Chad Wolf’s Ascension to “Acting Secretary” of
the DHS
In April 2019, Kirsjten Nielsen, on her last day of service 
as Secretary of Homeland Security, modified an order titled 
“DHS Orders of Succession and Delegations of Authority 
for Named Positions,” also known as Delegation 00106. 
Delegation 00106, both before and as amended, provided in 
subparts II.A–B: 
A. In  case  of  the  Secretary’s  death,
resignation, or inability to perform the

functions  of  the  Office,  the  orderly 
succession  of  officials  is  governed  by 
Executive  Order  13753,  amended  on 
December 9, 2016. 
B. I  hereby  delegate  to  the  officials
occupying the identified positions in the
order listed (Annex A), my authority to
exercise  the  powers  and  perform  the
functions and duties of my office, to the
extent not otherwise prohibited by law, in
the event I am unavailable to act during a
disaster or catastrophic emergency.
(emphasis added).  In a document titled “Amending the 
Order  of  Succession  in  the  Department  of  Homeland 
Security,” Secretary Nielsen invoked her authority under 6 
U.S.C.  § 113(g)(2),  and  “designate[d]  the  order  of 
succession  for  the  Secretary  of  Homeland  Security  as 
follow[ed].”    What  followed  were  instructions  to  strike 
Annex A and replace it with a new list, still titled “Annex A. 
Order for Delegation of Authority by the Secretary of the 
Department of Homeland Security.”  Notably,  Secretary 
Nielsen  did  not  change  the  text  of  Delegation  00106, 
subpart II.A; so, Annex A, both before and after Secretary 
Nielsen’s  order,  applied  only  to  delegations  occurring 
“during a disaster or catastrophic emergency.”  As a result, 
absent  a  delegation  during  a  disaster  or  catastrophic 
emergency,  subpart  II.A,  “the  orderly  succession  of 
officials” to the Secretary’s office, was still “governed by 
Executive Order 13753.” 
As of Secretary Nielsen’s last day in office, the list of 
names in Secretary Nielsen’s Annex A and Executive Order 
13753 differed.  Annex A listed (1) the Deputy Secretary of

10 GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS 
Homeland  Security,  (2) the  Under  Secretary  for

Protection (“CBP”), and (4) the Administrator of the Federal

In contrast, Executive Order 13753’s order of succession

CISA, Christopher Krebs, should have assumed the role of

The Constitution vests the President with the power and 
duty to nominate officers of the United States, subject to the 
advice and consent of the Senate.  U.S. Const. art. II, § 2, cl.

“exercis[es] significant authority pursuant to the laws of the
United States.”  Freytag v. Comm’r, 501 U.S. 868, 881

Vacancies in Executive offices arise frequently, and the
nomination and confirmation of a successor is rarely a swift
process.  As a practical—and often politically expedient—
workaround, the Executive Branch frequently turns to the
use  of  temporary,  or  “acting,”  officers  to  fill  vacant
positions.  The Legislative Branch has allowed this practice,
but it has also placed limits on it to ensure that reliance on
temporary officers does not usurp the Senate’s advice-and-
consent role.  See NLRB v. SW Gen., Inc., 580 U.S. 288, 294–
95 (2017).
The FVRA is Congress’s latest attempt to reign in the 
Executive Branch’s use of acting officers.  The FVRA’s 
predecessor, the Vacancies Act, dated to 1868.  See Act of 
July 23, 1868, ch. 227, 15 Stat. 168.  The Vacancies Act 
initially allowed temporary officers to serve for just 10 days 
in  most  circumstances,  a  grace  period  that  was  later 
lengthened to 30 days and then 120 days.  SW Gen., 580 U.S. 
at  294–95.    The  Vacancies  Act  did  not  impose  any 
consequences for the Executive Branch failing to comply 
with these limits, however.  See 15 Stat. 168.  For more than 
a century, the Vacancies Act was understood to be the sole 
means of temporarily filling vacancies in Executive offices. 
See Morton Rosenberg, Cong. Rsch. Serv., RL 98-892, The 
New Vacancies Act: Congress Acts to Protect the Senate’s 
Confirmation Prerogative 2 (1998) (Rosenberg).

workaround” to the FVRA.  Anne Joseph O’Connell, Actings, 120 
Colum. L. Rev. 613, 633 (2020).  But Professor O’Connell explained 
that she only “treats [agencies’ delegation practices] as permissible 
(though not necessarily desirable) under the” FVRA because they “are 
pervasive and have largely been upheld by the limited courts to consider 
them.”  Id. at 633 n.105.  Professor O’Connell’s careful observation 
about Executive Branch practice and the nascent state of the relevant 
caselaw did not endorse of agencies’ circumvention of the FVRA nor 
analyze the Act’s definition of “function or duty.”

64 GONZALES & GONZALES BONDS & INS. AGENCY, INC. V. USDHS 
few notable exceptions, but officials serving in violation of 
the Act have not been common.   
D 
With the meaning of “function or duty” in hand, the 
outcome of this appeal is straightforward.  Chad Wolf was 
without authority to issue the surety bonds rule because he 
was not properly acting as DHS Secretary under the FVRA. 
Congress directed only the DHS Secretary to promulgate 
surety bond rules.  See 8 U.S.C. § 1103(a)(3).  The issuance 
of surety bonds rules is a “function or duty” of the DHS 
Secretary within the meaning of § 3348(a)(2), so it follows 
under  § 3348(d)  that  Wolf’s  promulgation  of  the  surety 
bonds rule was without force or effect and could not be 
ratified by Wolf’s successor.   
III 
I  would  affirm  the  district  court’s  order  granting 
Plaintiff-Appellees’  motion  for  summary  judgment. 
Accordingly, I respectfully dissent.

N 18  jurisdiction will be granted if the complaint on its face fails to allege facts sufficient to establish 
19  subject matter jurisdiction.  See Savage v. Glendale Union High Sch., 343 F.3d 1036, 1039 n.2 
20  (9th Cir. 2003).  In considering a Rule 12(b)(1) motion, the Court “is not restricted to the face of 
21  the pleadings, but may review any evidence, such as affidavits and testimony, to resolve factual 
22  disputes concerning the existence of jurisdiction.”  McCarthy v. United States, 850 F.2d 558, 560 
23  (9th Cir. 1988).  Once a party has moved to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction under 
24  Rule 12(b)(1), the opposing party bears the burden of establishing the court’s jurisdiction.  See 
25  Chandler v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 598 F.3d 1115, 1122 (9th Cir. 2010). 
26  III.  DISCUSSION 
27  A.  Standing 
28  Article III standing requires the demonstration of three elements: (1) the plaintiff suffered 
2 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 33   Filed 07/13/21   Page 3 of 5
 
1  an “injury in fact” that is concrete and particularized and actual or imminent, not conjectural or 
2  hypothetical; (2) the injury is fairly traceable to the challenged action of the defendant; and (3) it is 
3  likely, as opposed to merely speculative, that the injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.  
4  Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560-61 (1992).  Absent this showing, the action 
5  must be dismissed.  See Steel Co. v. Citizens for a Better Env’t, 523 U.S. 83, 109-10 (1998). 
6  The Court finds that Plaintiffs have not established standing because Plaintiffs have not 
7  adequately alleged an injury in fact.  “[T]he Constitution mandates that prior to [a court’s] exercise 
8  of jurisdiction there exist a constitutional ‘case or controversy,’ that the issues presented are 
9  ‘definite and concrete, not hypothetical or abstract.’”  Thomas v. Anchorage Equal Rights 
10  Comm’n, 220 F.3d 1134, 1139 (9th Cir. 2000) (quoting Railway Mail Ass’n v. Corsi, 326 U.S. 88, 
11  93 (1945)).  To determine if jurisdiction is satisfied, the court “consider[s] whether the plaintiffs 
12  face a realistic danger of sustaining a direct injury as a result of the statute’s operation or 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  enforcement,’ or whether the alleged injury is too ‘imaginary’ or ‘speculative’ to support 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  jurisdiction.”  Id. (quoting Babbit v. United Farm Workers Nat’l Union, 442 U.S. 289, 298 (1979).  
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  “[N]either the mere existence of a proscriptive statute nor a generalized threat of prosecution,” 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  however, “satisfies the ‘case or controversy’ requirement.”  Id.  To determine there is a genuine 
S d nr
ee 17  threat of prosecution, the courts “look to whether the plaintiffs have articulated a ‘concrete plan’ to 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  violate the law in question, whether the prosecuting authorities have communicated a specific 
19  warning or threat to initiate proceedings, and the history of past prosecution or enforcement under 
20  the challenged statute.”  Id.  It is not enough to simply allege the provisions of the Final Rule; “the 
21  mere existence of a statute, which may or may not ever be applied to plaintiffs, is not sufficient to 
22  create a case or controversy within the meaning of Article III.”  San Diego Cty. Gun Rights Comm. 
23  v. Reno, 98 F.3d 1121, 1126 (9th Cir. 1996).  
24  Here, Plaintiffs’ only allegations regarding their potential injury are that they are “engaged 
25  in the business of posting immigration bonds on behalf of federally approved surety companies 
26  with DHS for, among other things, the release of aliens from detention pending a determination of 
27  the alien’s immigration status,” and that “they have been and will be injured by the Final Rule’s 
28  operation.”  (Compl. ¶¶ 13, 16-20.)  In their opposition, Plaintiffs assert that they will be required 
3

1  to file a $675 administrative appeal for every immigration bond that Defendant DHS determines to 
2  be breached.  (Pls.’ Opp’n at 10.)  In their complaint, however, Plaintiffs do not make any specific 
3  allegations that their bonds have ever been found to be breached, or that the breaches were 
4  wrongfully determined.  Without such information, it is not clear that Plaintiffs would ever have 
5  the opportunity or grounds to appeal a breach determination, and thus incur the injury of paying 
6  the $675 fee to appeal.  While it is possible that Plaintiffs may be injured by the Final Rule, a 
7  “possible future injury” is not enough; the threatened injury “must be certainly impending to 
8  constitute injury in fact.”  Clapper v. Amnesty Int’l USA, 568 U.S. 398, 409 (2013) (original 
9  emphasis).  
10  Likewise, Plaintiffs argue that the debarment provisions of the Final Rule are based on the 
11  breach determinations, which cannot be properly appealed under the Final Rule.  (Pls.’ Opp’n at 
12  5.)  As Plaintiffs’ injury due to the debarment provisions are based on their alleged inability to 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  appeal breach determinations, specific allegations demonstrating that Plaintiffs will need to appeal 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  a breach determination are necessary.  Absent such allegations, Plaintiffs’ injury is speculative.   
i
rts fo

et
tatsiD 16  satisfies Article III’s standing requirement.  Because Plaintiffs have failed to allege injury in fact, 
S d nr
ee 17  Plaintiffs have also failed to allege ripeness.  (See Pl.’s Opp’n at 7 (“Plaintiffs’ claims are ripe for 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the same reasons they have standing.”); Coons v. Lew, 762 F.3d 891, 897 (9th Cir. 2014) (“The 
19  constitutional component of the ripeness inquiry is often treated under the rubric of standing and, 
20  in many cases, ripeness coincides squarely with standing’s injury in fact prong.”).) 
21  B.  Venue 
22  In the alternative, Defendants argue that venue is improper in this district.  Under 28 
23  U.S.C. § 1391(e)(1), a civil action brought against the United States or its agencies and employees 
24  may be brought in any judicial district in which: “(A) a defendant in the action resides, (B) a 
25  substantial part of the events or omissions giving rise to the claim occurred . . . , or (C) the 
26  plaintiff resides if no real property is involved in the action.”  
27  Because the Court finds that there is no constitutional standing, and thus no jurisdiction 
28  over the case, the Court need not determine if venue was proper.  The Court observes, however, 
4 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 33   Filed 07/13/21   Page 5 of 5
 
1  that it appears Plaintiff Gonzales & Gonzales (“G&G”) is a California corporation located in 
2  California, and that Defendant DHS previously filed suit against Plaintiff G&G in this district in 
3  August 2009.  (See Compl. ¶ 16; United States v. Gonzales & Gonzales Bonds & Ins. Agency, Inc., 
4  Case No. 09-cv-4029-EMC (asserting venue under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b)(1) (“a judicial district in 
5  which any defendant resides”).)  Thus, it is not clear to the Court that venue is improper. 
6  IV.  CONCLUSION 
7  For the reasons stated above, the Court finds that Plaintiffs have not adequately alleged 
8  standing or ripeness, and that the Court therefore lacks jurisdiction over the case.  Amendment, 
9  however, does not appear to be futile, as Plaintiffs state that they can amend the complaint to 
10  include the number of bonds posted and deemed breached since the Final Rule was issued.  (Pls.’ 
11  Opp’n at 5.)  Accordingly, the Court GRANTS Defendants’ motion to dismiss without prejudice.  
12  Plaintiffs shall file an amended complaint within 21 days of the date of this order.

19  I.  BACKGROUND 
20  Plaintiffs are companies who post immigration bonds either as federally approved surety 
21  companies or on behalf of federally approved surety companies.  While removal proceedings are 
22  pending, Defendant Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”) often takes noncitizens into 
23  custody; however, once identified and processed, DHS may release noncitizens conditioned on 
24  posting a bond to guarantee that an individual appear upon request at either a DHS office or future 
25  hearing. See Procedures and Standards for Declining Surety Immigration Bonds and 
26  Administrative Appeal Requirement for Breaches, 85 Fed. Reg. 45,968-69 (July 31, 2020) (“the 
27  Final Rule”).  One way to post bond is by using a “surety bond,” which are guaranteed by 
28  companies certified to underwrite Federal bonds, who serve as co-obligors. See id. at 45,969.  As a 

Case 4:20-cv-08897-KAW   Document 67   Filed 08/10/22   Page 2 of 6
 
1  result, if the noncitizen fails to appear and DHS determines the bond to be breached, then the 
2  surety must pay a fixed sum to DHS as a result of the breach. Id. 
3  The Federal Vacancies Reform Act (“FVRA”) generally serves as the “exclusive means for 
4  temporarily authorizing an acting official” during a vacancy in a Senate-confirmed office, unless, 
5  in relevant part, a “statutory provision expressly . . . authorizes” the President, a court, or the head 
6  of a Department to designate an acting official or “designate[s] an officer or employee” to serve as 
7  the acting official. See 5 U.S.C. § 3347(a)(1).  The Homeland Security Act (“HSA”), 6 U.S.C. § 
8  113(g), is one such statute.  It provides that “[n]otwithstanding” the FVRA, the Under Secretary 
9  for Management shall serve as Acting Secretary in the event of vacancies in the offices of the 
10  Secretary and Deputy Secretary and that “the Secretary may designate such other officers of the 
11  Department in further order of succession to serve as Acting Secretary.” Id. § 113(g)(1)-(2). 
12  On April 10, 2019, Secretary of Homeland Security Kirstjen Nielsen resigned.  On April 9,

19  INS, 753 F.2d 766, 769 (9th Cir. 1985).  Instead, the Court “determines whether or not as a matter 
20  of law the evidence in the administrative record permitted the agency to make the decision it did.” 
21  Id. The APA permits a court to “hold unlawful and set aside agency action, findings and 
22  conclusions found to be - arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in 
23  accordance with law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). 
24  III.  DISCUSSION 
25  A.  Jurisdictional requirements  
26  As an initial matter, Defendants argue that “Plaintiffs have not satisfied the jurisdictional 
27  requirements of standing and ripeness….” (Defs.’ Opp’n at 1, 9-13.)  The undersigned, however, 
28  already found that Plaintiffs have satisfied these jurisdictional requirements, and nothing in

3  B.  Whether the Final Rule was lawfully promulgated. 
4    In moving for summary judgment, Plaintiffs argue that the Final Rule was improperly 
5  issued because Mr. Wolf was not validly appointed as Acting Secretary and the subsequent 
6  ratification by Secretary Mayorkas cannot revive the Final Rule. (Pls.’ Mot. at 1.) 
7  On October 19, 2021, the Court, in denying Defendant’s motion to dismiss, explained that 
8  it was persuaded by Behring Regional Center LLC v. Wolf, 544 F. Supp. 3d 937, 948 (N.D. Cal. 
9  2021), which “found that the invalid appointment of Kevin McAleenan invalidated the final rule 
10  issued, and that the after-the-fact ratification by Secretary Mayorkas could not cure the defect.” 
11  (Dkt. No. 44 at 8.)  The expanded briefing has not changed the Court’s analysis of this matter.  
12  Even so, the undersigned will briefly address the Government’s arguments, which have been

20  ii.  Ratification Cannot Revive the Final Rule. 
21  Here, Defendants again argue that Secretary Mayorkas’s ratification of the Final Rule 
22  cures any alleged defects in the rule arising from Chad Wolf’s service as Acting Secretary. (Def.’s 
23  Opp’n at 13.)  Specifically, Defendants argue that the Secretary delegated the authority to

26  Delegation, Decl. of Juliana Blackwell ISO Mot. to Dismiss, Dkt. No. 39-2 ¶ 2, Ex. 1.)  In the 
27  2003 Delegation, Secretary Ridge delegated certain delineated responsibilities including “[a]cting 
28  for the Secretary to sign, approve, or disapprove any proposed or final rule, regulation or related

1  document” to the Deputy Secretary of Homeland Security. (2003 Delegation at § II.G.)  This 
2  delegation, however, is inapplicable, because, by virtue of a vacancy, there was no Deputy 
3  Secretary of Homeland Security for which the authority to sign the Final Rule could be delegated. 
4  Indeed, it was this vacancy that led to Mr. McAllenan, as Senate-confirmed CBP Commissioner, 
5  to be named Acting Secretary. See Behring, 544 F. Supp. 3d at 947.  Thus, the Government’s 
6  arguments that there was delegation to the Deputy Secretary, of which there was not one, are

11  be ratified.’” Behring, 2021 WL 2554051, at *8 (quoting 5 U.S.C. § 3348(d)(2); also citing 5 
12  U.S.C. § 551(5) (“actions” include “rule making”)).  Thus, as is the case here, Mr. Wolf was not
